project.teaser: BACKGROUND: A vast majority of teenagers do not meet guidelines for healthy movement behaviours (i.e. physical activity, sedentary behaviour and sleep), posing major risks for developing multiple non-communicable diseases (NCDs). Sustainable implementation of lifestyle...
project.objective:
BACKGROUND: A vast majority of teenagers do not meet guidelines for healthy movement behaviours (i.e. physical activity, sedentary behaviour and sleep), posing major risks for developing multiple non-communicable diseases (NCDs). Sustainable implementation of lifestyle interventions focused on teenagers is a key challenge.
AIM: YoPAAPE aims to tailor, implement and evaluate social and physical environmental interventions for structural improvement in the lifestyle of teenagers (12-18 years) in vulnerable life situations to reduce their NCD risk.
APPROACH: YoPAAPE introduces teen-centred, evidence-informed co-creation to tackle the complex real-world challenge of unhealthy lifestyles and health inequalities. In urban environments in HICs (NL, DK) and LMICs (ZA, NG), we will engage teenagers and other key stakeholders in local co-creation communities. Together with academic researchers and local stakeholders, teenagers will take a leading role in 1) mapping the local system, including needs and opportunities; 2) tailoring interventions to the local context; 3) implementing, and 4) evaluating interventions guided by our novel SUPER-AIM framework assessing local Systems, User perspective, Participatory co-creation process, Reach, Effects, Adoption, Implementation, and Maintenance of interventions in an integrated manner.
IMPACT: All results will be integrated in an open access YoPAAPE toolbox targeted at researchers, public health practitioners and authorities, policy makers, and citizens. By establishing an infrastructure for teen-centred co-creation including capacity building, mentoring, and participation of teenager health advocates, YoPAAPE will nurture sustainable implementation of teenager-responsive preventive interventions tailored to the local context, improving their agency, movement behaviours and wellbeing, ultimately halting the rise of NCDs and associated healthcare costs.
project.title: A Youth-centred Preventive Action Approach towards co-created implementation of socially and Physically activating Environmental interventions
project.keywords: physical activity, movement behaviour, health promotion, participatory action research, co-creation, implementation

article.title: Environmental interventions to improve teen lifestyle

result.title: YoPAAPE co-creation protocol
result.description: Final version of protocol describing how to set up the co-creation communities in each setting and how to apply teen-centred co-creation including recruitment and methods for capacity building, and peer research as approved by ethics committee.

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 1 - YoPAAPE (A Youth-centred Preventive Action Approach towards co-created implementation of socially and Physically activating Environmental interventions)
result.teaser: Insufficient physical activity is associated with many non-communicable diseases (NCDs) and responsible for >5 million deaths worldwide each year. Public health guidelines recommend at least 60 minutes/day of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity for youth. An alarmingly low...

webItem.alternativeText: Youth-centred Participatory Action approach. IPT, initial programme theory.

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

result.title: Project Handbook
result.description: Collated support document on major internal aspects and arrangements for the project, including the objective for status updates to the EC project officer.

result.title: Mid-term recruitment report for co-creation groups
result.description: Report on recruitment of co-creation groups. At each local setting, co-creation groups will include a dynamic sample of 15-20 adolescents.

result.title: Project Identity including website
result.description: The YoPAAPE project identity, including logo, colour schemes and initial website, including the adaptations for each one of the participating cities.

result.title: Mid-term recruitment report on evaluation
result.description: Report on recruitment of evaluation sample. In total, a sample of 800-100 adolescents will be recruited for the evaluation.

result.title: Plan for dissemination and exploitation (PDE)
result.description: Report on communication, exploitation and dissemination planned activities, and norms and procedures involving the Impact Board

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
